Time to lament what I got wrong here: 
Questioned opened up 15 Dec 2015.  At that point, cyber was not in any specific countries sanctions list, though was a coverall E.O.  Sony hack was known and HR757 was in play against NK.  My view was that if 757 became law, if it included a prohibited activity referencing cyber this would count as a sanction.  Well 757 became law, EO 13722 (https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/nk_eo_20160316.pdf) was published March 15, 2016 and this now specifically prohibited transaction with NK due to it having engaged in significant activities undermining cybersecurity.  Fairly summarised here https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/114/hr757/summary, "“It imposes mandatory sanctions on individuals who contribute to North Korea’s nuclear and ballistic missile program, its malicious cyber-attacks, "".    OFAC agrees (https://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/nkorea.pdf) that under "E.O. 13722 blocks the property and interests in property of the Government of North Korea and the Workers’ Party of Korea... for ... engaged in significant activities undermining cybersecurity", but prohibited activities it turns out are not sanctions (for this q) and so this didnt count (section V of OFAC seemingly takes a different view, which was my view, but did not to resolve this q).  It seems to be have been successfully argued this is a framework and not an actual sanction, whereby to trigger a yes an individual or organisation in addition to the Government of NK needed to be blocked and added to the Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons (SDN List) to count.  Darn.
So then I patiently waited the 6 months for Obama to report on as per 757, turns out he didnt want to add anyone to the list, probably thinking NK Govt and Workers Party of Korea was enough.  Darn x 2.  
Then feint hope that the sanctions brought in response to the SWIFT attacks (http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/02/world/asia/treasury-imposes-sanctions-on-north-korea.html?_r=0) and  (from 38North: Sergei Shevchenko and Adrian Nish, “Cyber heist attribution,” BAE Systems Threat Research Blog, May 13, 2016, http://baesystemsai.blogspot.co.uk/2016/05/cyber-heist-attribution.html. See also: “SWIFT attacker’s malware linked to more financial attacks”; Symantec Official Blog, May 26, 2016, https://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/swift-attackers-malware-linked-more-financial-attack), but these were deemed sanctions already in prep not in response to, nor the final straw.  Darn x 3.
Overall, went too heavy too quickly and misunderstood it - going to hurt me along with other cyber miss.

Clips from WSJ article:
"The meddling in U.S. elections is another matter. In an unusual joint statement Friday, the Department of Homeland Security and Director of National Intelligence said that “the U.S. Intelligence Community (USIC) is confident that the Russian Government directed the recent compromises of e-mails from US persons and institutions, including from US political organizations.”
The U.S. spooks added that “the Russians have used similar tactics and techniques across Europe and Eurasia,” and that given the “scope and sensitivity” of these efforts “only Russia’s senior-most officials could have authorized these activities.” Senior-most is a euphemism for Mr. Putin.
One question is why the Obama Administration has gone public with this hacking news now. One reason might be to warn Russia against dumping more of the U.S. documents it almost certainly has before Election Day. But then Russia’s hacking habits are hardly new, and Mr. Putin is still harboring the national-security thief Edward Snowden. Just for the record, I'm going to reiterate my claim that this question resolved positively long ago, and has failed to do so based on an improper understanding of how sanctions are implemented. In short, a set of claims as to bad actions are codified into a supraset called "national emergency." Then, sanctions (the "penalties") are imposed as against the national emergency. That this is the fundamental logic of sanctions, and not a tit-for-tat logic, is evidenced by the need to continue the proclamations of "national emergency." Else, each (falsely believed) tit-for-tat sanction would be allowed to continue on its own, and continuing proclamations would be unnecessary.

In 2016 there has been an uptick in ransomware attacks on increasingly large organizations (http://wbtw.com/2016/02/16/horry-county-schools-approve-paying-computer-virus-ransom-making-payment-problematic/). While initial observations would indicate payoff as the goal of such attacks, it appears to me that these attacks have targeted organizations with resources sufficient to defend themselves but without resources sufficient to go after the perpetrators.  From a programming development standpoint it appears these attacks are more of a test of skill than an actual desire for the payout.  This would indicate a large, probably state-sponsored, organization that is testing out new intrusion methodologies. As such, the prospect of state-sponsored attacks increases the likelihood of charges related to such attacks. Mitigating factors include the political fallout associated with such a charge, as well as the difficulty of a government convincing its citizenry that such an attack occurred and was committed by a particular state actor.

The response - imposition structure of sanctions. Here's another example of the basic response - imposition structure of a complex sanction act. In this case, the response is couched in terms of a "national emergency," which included. among other things, "the existence and risk of the proliferation of weapons-usable fissile material on the Korean Peninsula." These constituent things are those which create the "national emergency." It is the national emergency, and derivatively the constituent things, that are being responded to. (In the case of the recent North Korea Sanctions Act, it was the "crisis," and its derivative constituents, that was being responded to.) The imposition, in the case of these OFAC programs, are "blocked transactions." While there are criteria for entities selected for imposition (e.g., being an official of the Workers’ Party of Korea), these criteria are independent of any criteria that may have been used to identify or attribute the underlying derivative constituent things causing the national emergency. If there is any correlation between these two sets of criteria, it is coincidental, and not necessarily required within the notion of a sanction.

I Modeled this problem as a poisson process with mean cyber sanction arrivals of 1 in 5 years for USA, 1 in 10 years for each of Germany, France, and Canada, and 1 in 10 years for others combined for an overall average arrival rate of 6 sanction events in 10 years. Using the poisson model, the probability of 1 or more sanction events this year is 1-exp(-0.6*(days left in year/366)). I don't have a strong basis for my mean arrival rate estimates since there's not a long history of cyber sanctions. For comparison, if I chose 1 in 3 years for the USA, and 1 in 5 years for each of Germany, France, Canada, and other, then the probability of cyber sanctions would jump to 52%. [NOTE: wave arms wildly w.r.t independence assumptions of the poisson model]

The key point in this question is the imposition of sanctions. There will most likely be cyber attacks and cyber espionage, there may even be threats of sanctions in response. The problem is that it is fiendishly fraught to assign blame to a state for one of these attacks. The nature of cyber attacks means that the responsible party is obscured. So the first thing we would need to see this year is a significant cyber attack that warrants state-level sanctions. As soon as it happens (I'd give it 30% chance in the next 12 months), the clock is then ticking for the investigation to start and conclude within the calendar year. Most likely this investigation would take several months, and I'm willing to predict that it would take more than 6 months, and 80% chance a year or longer. Then there would be a lot of political bluster and posturing before imposition of sanctions; might take a week to two months maybe? So with an attack needing to occur in the first half of the year for a low chance for a conclusion and imposition of sanctions within 2016, I give the overall chance of this a low score.

I think the term “Cyber Attack” s a bit too vague. There are different types of cyber-ofenses:
Cyber-attack is any type of offensive maneuver employed by individuals or whole organizations that targets computer information systems, infrastructures, computer networks, and/or personal computer devices by various means of malicious acts usually originating from an anonymous source that either steals, alters, or destroys a specified target by hacking into a susceptible system. This type of attack can be perpetrate by a group of teens with too much free time; by professional hackers working on their own or for a country; or by legitimate countries.
Cyber spying, or cyber espionage, is the act or practice of obtaining secrets without the permission of the holder of the information (personal, sensitive, proprietary or of classified nature), from individuals, competitors, rivals, groups, governments and enemies for personal, economic, political or military advantage. CE, well almost every country does it, In fact in September 2015, the United States and China agreed not to allow parties in their nations to cyberspy on each other for commercial gain, but did not prohibit government spying.
Cyber-terrorism is “the use of computer network tools to shut down critical national infrastructures (such as energy, transportation, government operations) or to coerce or intimidate a government or civilian population. CT is the most dangerous one.
We could split hairs even more than that, but it should suffice for now.

I am really struggling with this question. Although a framework for sanctions which result from cyber attacks is not clear, I nevertheless believe that some named entity will put together some claim of leveling sanctions against some country in response to malicious cyber activity within the time horizon. Further, I do not believe GJ has demonstrated the inclination or the capacity to properly vet the accuracy of such a claim; reserving for itself an arbitrary "GJ fudge factor." applied retroactively at whim if necessary. I am, therefore, changing my forecast to the positive side.

I am still trying to work out what a country-specific sanction (as opposed to an individual or corporate sanction) would look like. One possibility might be that it would be a ban of an entire set or class of individual or corporate types originating from within a particular country based on product or service. For example, as with the Russian reverse-sanction-sanction of banning importation of food categories from selected countries. Would a ban in the United States on the importation of any rug made in Iran be a sanction on Iran or the carpet-makers? Provided the ban is universal ("all carpets from X") I think we could say it was a sanction against X, not just the carpet-makers. So, what universal-type bans would be an appropriate response for a cyber-attack? There's also a difference between export and import bans. They may have comparable symbolism, but export bans are more difficult to enforce. Further, there is also consideration of the specific nature of the economic trade existing between the two relevant nations. Sanctions on the importation of product A from country X might be quite strong, if the export of product A by country X is meaningful. So, in particular circumstances, tying matchsticks or coconuts to cyber-attacks might not be far-fetched at all. Bans on imports also usually incur some cost to the importer. So sanctions, via bans, are a rich area with a lot of flexibility ranging over symbolism to economic effects. If cyber warfare continues as it has, no doubt such cyber-sanctions are to follow. Perhaps there is a joint NSA, Treasury, State department working group within the U.S. actively developing a framework for these now. At this point, however, I haven't caught wind of any such framework. There is also the complication that cyber-warfare is handled within the military command structure, so an integrated economic response might be out of the realm of their expertise, and not even a part of their solution domain.

Cyber attacks will certainly occur, but sanctions are a very unlikely response. Firstly, it is very difficult to prove the source of attacks. Secondly, sanctions require a fair amount of international consensus. Thirdly, it is worth keeping in mind that the U.S. and EU probably undertake similar actions themselves. Finally even if cyber attacks did prompt some sanctions in the future, the formal justification for them will probably be given as something else (human rights etc) thereby preventing a YES outcome to this question.
